trustfund:
TF026127-PHRD-FIRST PUBLIC SECTOR REFORM LOAN,TF039175-JORDAN - GOVERNMENT COMPUTER
            CAPACITY BUILDING IMPROVEMENT

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Public Sector Reform
            for Jordan are as follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, the Bank and borrower performance were
            both satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that
            programmatic lending serves as a useful vehicle for
            economy-wide reforms. Nevertheless, with a complex operation
            the size of the Public Sector Reform Loan (PSRL), a frank
            and informal dialogue and communication at all stages of the
            programs becomes all the more crucial for the Bank and its
            country counterparts. There is a need for the creation of a
            Steering Committee at the Cabinet Level with a mandate to
            oversee and monitor PSRL's progress, particularly on
            the improved delivery of public services as well as for
            pursuing a proactive communications strategy targeted to the
            intended beneficiaries. In this regard, the GoJ has recently
            established such a steering committee headed by the Minister
            of Planning and includes as its members the Ministers of
            Justice, Administrative Development, Finance,
            Telecommunications and Information Technology, and Industry
            ands Trade. The committee has been given the mandate to
            oversee and monitor the public sector reform program.
            Progress toward Medium-Term Expenditure Framework (MTEF) and
            the integration of investment and current budgets within the
            Ministry of Finance (MoF) should be accompanied by
            commensurate budget preparation capabilities in the line
            ministries. Parallel efforts need to be made within the
            Ministry of Planning (MoP) for the formulation and
            monitoring of the PIP (critical to the implementation of
            NSETP). It is essential to develop monitoring and evaluation
            capacity-for evaluating the both the progress of policies
            and programs underpinning the entire reform program.
